title: josh-taylor-reveals-opponent-first-defence-world-titles
story: The Prestonpans super lightweight champion ndash who added the WBA belt to his IBF title by beating highly rated American Regis Prograis on points in the final of the World Boxing Super Series in London last October ndash will have to fulfil his mandatory obligation against -year-old Khongsong before turning his attention to locking horns with WBC and WBO belt holder Jose Ramirez in a unication bout.Like Taylor, Khongsong, who is the IBFs mandatory challenger, has won all of his  bouts, but the Thai boxer has only fought once outside of his home country.Taylor is dreaming of getting his hands on all four belts in the lbs ision but will also have to wait for the outcome of Ramirezrsquos defence against Ukrainian Viktor Postol on February .Postol and Taylor have already squared off, having fought each other in the summer of .The fight, which took place at the SSE Hydro in Glasgow, saw Taylor emerge with a unanimous points decision over Postol, who previously held the WBC title.Taylor said: ldquoRamirez has the mandatory against Postol in February and I have to do it with my IBF belt with this guy from Thailand.ldquoI need to get that out of the way and he needs to get Postol out of the way.ldquoEvenPostol comes through that hersquoll be the guy I want because hersquoll have the two belts.Taylor, who split with Barry McGuigans Cyclone Promotions last week after signing with American promoters Top Rank, is hoping to be on home soil against Khongsong but concedes he will likely have to travel across the Atlantic for a potential bout with American Ramirez.Speaking to IFLTV, he added: ldquoIrsquom hoping Irsquoll have a defence in Scotland before then going Stateside to chase the Ramirez fight.ldquoI canrsquot see Ramirez coming over here, Irsquod push for it but I have to go to America.ldquoIrsquoll go there and see my name up in bright lights."The future is bright and I canrsquot wait to get going.ldquoThat fight has to happen at some point this year, thats my goal and focus, becoming undisputed king and be the first [Scottish] man to do it since Ken Buchanan.

title: busy-stretch-tranent-road-shut-gas-works
story: Tranentrsquos Church Street will be closed between High Street and the junction with Sandersonrsquos Wynd for six weeks from next Monday .The closure is to allow a pound, upgrade of the gas network in the area.A leaflet produced by SGN, which is behind the works, states: ldquoFor the duration of the six-week project, Church Street will be closed between its junctions with Sandersonrsquos Wynd and High Street.ldquoThere will also be no access to Church Street from Sandersonrsquos Wynd or Winton Place.ldquoFor the first two to three weeks of our work, wersquoll also have three-way temporary traffic lights in place at the junction with Bridge Street, High Street and Winton Place.ldquoWe will be manually controlling the lights at peak time to ease traffic congestion.ldquoParking suspensions in surrounding streets will be in place on Bridge Street, Church Street, Winton Place and High Street.Councillor Colin McGinn, who represents the town on East Lothian Council, said that the roadworks would cause ldquoupheaval but the gas works were necessary.He told the Courier: ldquoI think it is going to cause disruption.ldquoIt is one of those bits of work that, no matter when you do it, it is going to cause an inconvenience.Mr McGinn was also keen for the local authority to keep an eye on the works, particularly amid fears that surrounding streets, such as Coal Neuk, could be used as a rat run.Temporary Traffic Regulation Ordersare being drawn up by East Lothian Council, with temporary changes made to Winton Place to allow access to the George Johnstone Centre.Access to Sandersonrsquos Wynd will be available from Tranent Mains Road and Coalgate Road.Any queries, contact SGN on   .

title: east-links-family-park-founder-looking-take-gorgie-city-farm
story: The Edinburgh tourist attraction closed its doors last year due to financial dficulties.However, Grant Bell is keen to head up a community interest company which would see the farm opened up once again.He said: ldquoGorgie City Farm was one of the parks back in the day before East Links was created that I visited.ldquoI used photographs from Gorgie City Farm and Heads of Ayr [Farm Park] when I went to the planners with the kind of thing East Links could be.ldquoWe have a long history and traded animals for years back and forwards.Mr Bell, who opened East Links Family Park, near West Barns, in , was determined not to see the city farm remain closed.Instead, he wants it ed to its former glory, with few changes planned, other than providing somewhere with ldquoa decent cup of coffee for the facility.A statement on the tourist attractionrsquos website reads: ldquoUnfortunately, Gorgie City Farm is now closed.ldquoAfter exploring all our options, it is with huge regret that the farm has been unable to find a route to a sustainable future.ldquoWe are very grateful to all staff, volunteers, customers and donors who have supported us over the last  years.Mr Bell was aiming to make Gorgie City Farm ldquosustainable.He said: ldquoI want to keep it exactly the same ndash just farm animals and education about food and farming.ldquoI just want to get it back open and hopefully the people of Edinburgh will appreciate it.Mr Bell is one of two interested parties still in the running to potentially take over the farm.Joining him in expressing an interest is mental health charity Love Learning.Liquidator Shona Campbell, of MHA Henderson Loggie, said a decision would be made by the end of the month. A spokeswoman said: ldquoThe bidders are mental health charity Love Learning and Mr Grant Bell, owner of East Links Family Park.ldquoA consortium involving the homeless charity Cyrenians, which had previously expressed an interest, has pulled out of the process.ldquoMHA Henderson Loggie will now assess the bids before making recommendations to site landlord City of Edinburgh Council.ldquoA decision on the future of the site will be announced before the end of January.East Links Family Park, which celebrated its one millionth visitor five years ago, has a number of attractions including a soft play barn, go karts and crazy golf, as well as a wide range of both indoor and outdoor animals.Mr Bell added: ldquoI have a particular set of skills.ldquoI am a chap that comes from a farming background.ldquoI have always been interested in food and farming in the countryside and happy for visitors to come and see the farm and enjoy it.

title: north-berwick-high-school-pupils-interviewed-newsround
story: Murron Sinclair, Martha Blacklock, Charlie Bowdler, Evie Drysdale, Rab Ellis and Fergus Kinnaird, all  years old, were chosen by their teachers to take part.The aim of the interview, which took place last Thursday, was to ask the S pupils their thoughts on Scotland and a potential second independence referendum.However, a story that broke that morning about the Scottish Football Association banning children under  from heading a ball in training sessions meant the pupils were asked an additional question and appeared on the show in two separate bulletins.The Newsround team decided toto the town having visited North Berwick before when working on a plastic pollution story and have also previously visited Law Primary School.The team were speaking to three other schools during their trip to Scotland and wanted to make sure they got opinions from a iety of backgrounds and areas.In preparation for the big day, the pupils met with Georgina Brownlee, principal teacher of the schoolrsquos humanities department, two days before to find out what was going to happen and rehearse some answers.Before filming began, all of the children were nervous and scared in case they made any mistakes.Martha said: ldquoI was thinking I didnrsquot want to say the wrong thing or mess up what I was going to say.ldquoI know they can cut it but you still get a bit nervous but yoursquore also excited as yoursquore going on TV.Evie agreed and added: ldquoI didnrsquot want to sound like I didnrsquot know what I was doing.Murron said: ldquoThe thing I was most nervous about was looking straight down into a camera.Charlie added: ldquoI felt more excited than nervous. I felt relief that [the other pupils] were doing it as well becauseit was just me Irsquod feel really scared.Fergus had butterflies in his stomach and thought that being the last one to speak made them worse!The pupils were split into three pairs and asked five questions each.The first asked what they loved about Scotland, with the countryrsquos rich history, great inventors and gorgeous countryside mentioned.The pupils were then askedthey thought Scotland should be able to make its own decisions, what they thought the benefits of staying and leaving the UK were, should Scotland take back control of its own priorities and their thoughts on Boris Johnson not allowing another independence referendum.A wide range of answers were given to all of the questions, ranging from ldquoitrsquos our country and our future, we should get a say in what happens and ldquoScottish people have the right to vote as Scotland gets overpowered by England to ldquoour future could be very uncertain.Filming finished earlier than anticipated, with everyone notably a lot more relaxed afterwards.Murron and Evie were both excited to see themselves on national TV, with Murron adding: ldquoIrsquom also nervous because I donrsquot want people to come at me for my own opinion ndash I donrsquot want people to say I was wrong.Martha said: ldquoI feel quite proud that Irsquove done something like this because Irsquove never been on TV before. Irsquom almost kind of relieved that itrsquos done but also very happy with what wersquove done.The boys were equally as relieved and happy with their work, saying it was a great experience.However, the occasion was dferent than they thought it would be.The boys thought they would be greeted by five reporters, three cameras and a green screen, but only having two people, a reporter and cameraman, was a lot less daunting.All of the pupils said their parents were very excited to see them on TV and that their experience had inspired them to consider a possible career in the industry.Mrs Brownlee was very proud of the pupils and the answers they produced.She added: ldquoIt was a great opportunity and a great chance to have the kidsrsquo voices heard. The Newsround team really made them feel at ease.ldquoI quite like watching how they do it all, itrsquos really interesting.The football segment was aired last Friday and can be viewed at bbc newsround The independence piece will air next Thursdayon the .am, .am and pm bulletins.Newsround is shown on the CBBC channel and is a news show aimed at children between the ages of six and .

title: foundations-place-long-awaited-port-seton-sports-hall
story: Work on the pound million extension started last October and is due to be completed by July.The erection of the steel frame means residents can see how big the new sports hall will be.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, cabinet member for community wellbeing, said: ldquoPort Seton Centre is a much-used and valued facility in the heart of this community and there has been a long-held desire to expand its footprint to increase leisure access.ldquoOur investment will support existing services and also allow new activities to be developed.ldquoIrsquom pleased to see the progress that has been made so far and look forward to watching it continue to take shape.Marlene Love from the Port Seton Community Centre management committee said: ldquoIrsquom absolutely delighted to finally see the extension happening.ldquoItrsquos been needed for so long and itrsquos been a lot of work to make it happen.ldquo Irsquom so pleased to see it coming to fruition.Following feedback from the local community, East Lothian Council commissioned a sports hall feasibility study, which identied that the sports and leisure facilities at the existing centre were not good enough.

title: ham-sandwiches-schools-binned-date-mix-up
story: Parents were sent a message last Friday from East Lothian Council alerting them to the problem.The ham in the sandwiches was labelled with the wrong expiry date and pupils were asked to throw them away as a precaution.The schools affected were East Linton Primary, Gullane Primary, Knox Academy in Haddington, Law Primary in North Berwick, Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary in Musselburgh, Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary in Tranent and Preston Lodge High School in Prestonpans.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoOur supplier made us aware last Friday of a product recall for roast ham, which had been provided to us for inclusion in that dayrsquos packed lunches.ldquoThe supplier informed us that an incorrect use by date had been labelled on some of the products.ldquoAs a matter of priority, we used our schools text alert system to advise parents that the ham sandwiches provided should be disposed of not consumed.ldquoSafety is paramount and we have a duty of care to all our children and young people.ldquoAs a matter of priority, our facilities management team, in consultation with environmental health, have been working with the supplier to understand the issue.ldquoWhile we believe that the incorrectly labelled ham had been dispatched to a minority of our schools, it was felt appropriate to send advice to parents at all schools as a precaution."We apologise for the inconvenience caused and can assure parents that we will continue to work with the supplier to ensure any lessons are learned for the future.

title: work-starting-ahead-railway-station-returning-east-linton
story: Campaigners have been calling for a station toto the village, on the East Coast Main Line, for more than  years.Currently, it is planned that the station will be open before , with campaigners calling for it to be in place as soon as possible.Now, a letter has been sent out to village residents highlighting upcoming work in the area.The letter reads: ldquoWe will shortly begin survey work and site investigation activity on railway land in your neighbourhood.ldquoThis work is required to help the design of a new station at East Linton.ldquoOur work will involve detailed survey activities, which may require us to cut back some vegetation.ldquoOur site investigation work also requires us to use drilling equipment to check ground conditions in proposed development sites.ldquoWhere possible, the work will be carried out during the day.ldquoHowever, some of our investigations need to be undertaken on the railway embankment or directly underneath the tracks.ldquoIn order to access these locations, we will need to carry out the work at night while trains are not operating.ldquoDuring this period of work, we will have a small compound located on site to provide facilities for our staff.ldquoThe compound will be set up from Saturday February  until our work is complete and will be located adjacent to the railway, with access taken through Orchardfield Estate, East Linton.The works come at the same time as East Lothian MSP, Iain Gray, has cautiously welcomed a response from Scotlandrsquos transport secretary on the progress of the station.Michael Mathesonrsquos response to written parliamentary questions from Mr Gray, which he submitted in light of the decision to end the Abellio ScotRail contract three years early, indicated that Network Rail are progressing with the station designs with the intention of submitting a planning application later this year.Alongside the work required for completing the station, the cabinet secretary also highlighted that an industry working group is developing plans for the December  East Coast Main Line timetable, including services for East Linton.Mr Gray was pleased progress was being made but vowed to keep the pressure on to ensure there were no delays.He said: ldquoFollowing the governmentrsquos decision to cut short Abelliorsquos ScotRail franchise, I asked parliamentary questions about progress on delivering East Lintonrsquos new rail station in order to ensure the franchise decision will not affect the project.ldquoThankfully, while the replies from Mr Matheson have not provided an exact date for the completion of the project, they have offered some reassurance that the project is progressing and the new station should be delivered by  at the latest.ldquoThat is good news for people in East Linton who have been waiting such a long time for this important new infrastructure.ldquoHowever, while the progress is welcome, there is still a signicant way to go to before it is finalised and benefitting the local community.ldquoGiven all the delays we have endured, Irsquom fully committed to maintaining the pressure on Ministers to ensure the station is delivered.East Linton previously had a railway station, which closed in .It is expected the new station will be created to the west of the previous version.

title: woman-took-valium-drove-mcdonalds
story: Ellie Watson arrived at the takeaway drive-thru at Fort Kinnaird behind the wheel of a vehicle and attempted to order food for her and her partner, who was sitting beside her.But staff soon believed the woman was under the influence of alcohol or drugs and called in the police after serving her.Officers arrived at the premises at about .am on July  last year, where they spotted Watsonrsquos vehicle in the car park.And when they spoke to the -year-old, the constables noted the woman was ldquolethargic and slurring her words and took her into custody.Watson gave a breath test soon after and also had to give a blood sample a few hours later after she had been taken to St Leonardrsquos Police Station, Edinburgh.Police officers then discovered Watson, of Delta Drive, had only a provisional driving licence and also held no valid insurance for the car.Watson appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Wednesday, where she pleaded guilty to four charges.Fiscal depute Miss Stuart told the court that Watson had previously pleaded guilty by letter and was driving a white Vauxhall Corsa when she pulled into the takeaway car park at about .am.The fiscal said that an employee spotted Watson was ldquohaving trouble driving the car and suspected her of being under the influence of a substance when she was ldquostruggling to speak when ordering the food.Solicitor Paul Smith said his client was expecting her first child in April and the offence had been ldquoa very poor error of judgement.Mr Smith added that Watson had taken Valium at a friendrsquos home earlier that evening and now ldquoaccepts she was unfit to drive the vehicle.The brief said that Watson was a care worker and was currently a single woman and living alone.Sherf Roderick Flinn told the woman that she had committed ldquoa serious offence and banned her from driving for  months. The sherf also issued Watson with a pound fine.Watson pleaded guilty to driving a vehicle with only a provisional licence at McDonaldrsquos car park, Kinnaird Park, Edinburgh, on July  last year.She also admitted a further three charges of having no valid insurance, being unfit to drive through drink or drugs, and failing to give police details of the driver of the vehicle during the same incident.

title: new-plans-revamping-ship-inn-musselburgh
story: At the end of last year, owner Caledonian Heritable Ltd got the go-ahead from East Lothian Council to carry out alterations and extensions to the North High Street building.The company was also remaining in place until the end of this month.Also approved at the end of last year were alterations to the pub, a single-storey extension to the rear of the building, the infilling of the vehicular access in the wall of the car park with a new wall, and erection of a new wall with pedestrian access to enclose part of the boundary of the seating area.Another planning application for the the lsquoflatrsquo entrance.A council spokesperson said: ldquoThe new application, which does include elements previously approved, will now be considered on its own merits.ldquoPrevious approval does not necessarily mean that the new changes will be accepted.The changes were detailed by the council as: three new window openings at first-floor level on the southern elevation two new window openings title: tims-tales-stars-sky
story: I HAVE a term: the lsquoupside down skyrsquo. I use this phrase to describe the spectacle of street lights at night when viewed from a vantage point.One of the best places in East Lothian to view the lsquoupside down skyrsquo is from the road by Farsquoside Castle. This vantage point gives you views over Wallyford, Musselburgh, Portobello and Edinburgh beyond.These urban areas create a sea of lights which look like a sky full of bright stars, except, of course, itrsquos lsquoupside downrsquo and theyrsquore not really stars. But it looks spectacular in its own way. In fact, views with bright city lights are these days often considered tourist attractions.But Irsquove recently realised something: while the lsquostarsrsquo of the lsquoupside down skyrsquo are getting more numerous and extensive every year, the real stars in the actual sky are becoming more dficult to see at least where I live.Literally thousands upon thousands of houses are being built in the western part of our county. Much of the rural landscape in this part of East Lothian, which I knew when I was a child, is going fast.Most of me understands and accepts the needs for this, but a part feels sad at the loss of a recognisable landscape. And already I have noticed that a by-product of this has been increased light pollution in areas close to where I live. It is going to get much more noticeable as more development takes place.I know many people will say there are many more things to think about, especially in late January, when the Christmas turkey is coming home to roost and all those bills have to be paid at a time when we are already financially drained from festive expenditure, and stressed out. Thank goodness for Burns suppers, a highlight of a month that often seems both the darkest and longest of the year.But this is all the more reason to pause. When was the last time you really had the opportunity to sit under a dark night sky full of visible stars  This is one of naturersquos free gts and stargazing has real benefits for our mental health and emotional wellbeing.I remember some years ago, when visiting a friend in a very rural part of Scotland, I went out to put something in the bin. My friend came out to seeI was OK, as I hadnrsquot ed after  minutes. I had been struck by the beauty and power of the starlit sky, unpolluted by city lights. Without noticing the time, I had sat just gazing at the universe above me.I can remember the sense of awe and peace it created. Sure, part of it was also the quiet and stillness in that area, but sitting under the canopy of stars is what overwhelmed me in that moment.Itrsquos an experience fewer of us can enjoy because of the increase in light pollution, but also noise and general busyness all around us. So we often donrsquot even realise what wersquore missing. Perhaps there is a cause and effect here: the less you notice the absence of something, the less you think itrsquos important or relevant.Our ancient ancestors understood its power. But I think we have lost the sense. I recently asked a group of young people how many of them had sat under the stars and just gazed and wondered at them. Sadly, none had done so, and some thought the idea ldquoweird. I think a lot of adults would share that opinion.But taking time to sit and really wonder at an unpolluted night sky can fill us with awe, as I experienced that evening at my friendrsquos house. It makes us feel small and in so doing it puts our worries and anxieties in perspective. It can promote inner peace and calm.For sure, the bills wonrsquot go away neither will the stress at work or whatever is dominating your thoughts most of the day. But in taking time to pause and wonder at the vast and almost timeless beauty of the stars, your soul gets time to catch up. It can help you see things dferently, in a more creative way. Itrsquos a form of meditation with something bigger than we can imagine, but also something incredibly beautul.And itrsquos fascinating, as you try to identy the dferent constellations, and perhaps realise how much you donrsquot know or have forgotten. Could you identy the northern star, and what constellations can you see  Sailors in days of old were experts at identying the stars to aid direction, but Irsquom sure they also marvelled at the unhindered beauty and mystery of them as well.There are still many places in our county where we can be wrapped in star-lit darkness. But as the lsquoupside down skyrsquo gets bigger and brighter, the real stars are fading in so many places.The real shame is, as the stars disappear from our sight, they may disappear from our consciousness as well.Letrsquos not let that happen. Let us gt our children, and ourselves, with the noticing and gazing at the real stars in our sky and somehow find the time, even briefly, to stargaze.

title: garry-oconnor-referees-haddington-amateur-teams-successful-charity-match
story: Haddington Town FC took time out over the festive period for a special friendly in aid of Back Onside.Former Hibernian and Scotland striker Garry OrsquoConnor, who is an ambassador of the good cause, refereed the match, which saw members of the amateur teamrsquos squad come up against one another on January .Matt OrsquoConnell, chairman of the club, which was formed last year, said they were determined to help support the charity, which helps young people and adults who face mental health challenges.He said: ldquoWersquore a club that was founded on the idea of bringing local guys together into a positive social and active environment.ldquoItrsquos well documented that the highest proportion of suicide across Scotland is men aged - and thatrsquos something we hope to positively redress in our town by facilitating a great environment in which local guys can improve not only their physical but also their mental health.ldquoOur connection with the charity Back Onside was really born of their slogan, #SupportThroughSport, a powerful statement that really resonated with us.ldquoTheyrsquore a great charity who are doing a hell of a lot across the UK and so for us, a small amateur club barely nine months old, to play a small part in helping a charity who share our ethos was immensely rewarding.Haddington Town play on Sunday mornings in Division Two of the Lothian and Edinburgh Amateur Football Association , alongside fellow county side Meadowmill.The charity match, played at Knox Academy, finished - in favour of the lsquoawayrsquo Haddington Town team.Libby Emmerson, founder and CEO of Back Onside, said: ldquoWe are beyond grateful for the support received from Haddington Town Amateur Football Club and guest referee Garry OrsquoConnor.ldquoAs a small charity with a huge clientele, community events such as the Haddington Town AFC charity match are key to raising funds and awareness so that we can continue to support those facing mental health challenges.Mr OrsquoConnell thanked everyone for their support, with the match raising pound, ndash more than double the target.He said: ldquoHuge thanks to Libby Emmerson, FES FM and Garry OrsquoConnor. We would also like to thank the local businesses who helped us: The Green, The Grain, Tyneside Tavern and Print Factory Scotland.

title: brewery-shuts-ahead-archerfield-walled-garden-redevelopment-plan
story: Knops moved into Archerfield and opened the brewery in , occupying a third of the available space.However, with refurbishment plans in the works and the breweryrsquos lease on the space up for renewal at the end of last year, rather than grant renewal, a decision was made to close the brewery, a decision described as the ldquomost sensible thing to do.Robert Knops, owner of Knops Brewery, decided to close the brewery for good rather than carry on in a dferent venue.Some of Knopsrsquo most popular beers included Black Cork, Calornia Common and East Coast Pale Ale.Plans to overhaul Archerfield Walled Garden have been in the works for the past couple of years.Ross McGregor, director of operations for Archerfield Estates Limited, said: ldquoThose at the brewery have done a really fantastic job over the years.ldquoTheyrsquove known about the closure for the past two years because thatrsquos how long we have been planning this [refurbishment] for.ldquoSome of the plans on the table include re-doing the entire inside of the building and turning it into a garden shop along with updating our cafe and food market.ldquoThe project is a major refurbishment and we hope to improve a lot of areas to make better use of the space we have, for example to help in dealing with events.He added: ldquoThis is a really positive thing for the area. The business has been growing over the last few years and now we are adding to that. We aim to make it slicker for the customer as well as a simpler and more beautul place.Plans for the upgrade, which are still to be finalised, could see the walled garden take on an even greater garden and floral theme.Other plans include an expansion to the cafe, with hopes the food used there could be grown on site.The childrenrsquos area could also see a revamp with a covered outdoor area containing an extra - seats.Planning permission for the renovation has been approved and work is set to begin either later on this year or early next year.Mr McGregor said: ldquoWe are now working with the building contractors to decide on when this will be completed.ldquoIrsquom hoping it will be this year but it all depends on the building warrant and what timescale the builders come back with.The business will need to close for about two months when the work is going on but it is not yet known when this will happen.

title: shock-bouquet-popular-hairdressers-grave-vanishes
story: Melvin died on September  after succumbing to heart failure while on holiday in Tenere aged .His daughter, -year-old Hannah, who works as an accident and emergency nurse in Glasgow, bought the winter-themed bouquet and placed it on his grave in the cemetery at Athelstaneford on Christmas Eve.His we Lorna, who lives near Gilmerton House and visits Melvinrsquos grave regularly, told the Courier: ldquoMy daughter visited the cemetery to place the bouquet and Irsquod placed a wreath which I bought for him beforehand.ldquoMelvin loved Christmas and decorations so we put something there to give him some nice Christmas surroundings.ldquoI went back on December  and it was still there but when I went back on January  it was gone, the vase and wreath were still there but the flowers werenrsquot.ldquoI looked everywhere and even asked a member of staff but couldnrsquot find it. I think someone has stolen it.She added: ldquoIrsquom really shocked because I just canrsquot understand why someone would do something like this.ldquoThe whole thing is very untoward, absolutely disgusting, and has made me quite upset. Itrsquos quite obvious itrsquos at a grave so I donrsquot know why someone would take it.ldquoI thought it might have been an animal or that someone had moved it to a dferent grave, so I looked around each grave but they all still had their flower decorations.Lorna added: ldquoHannah is just really hurt and upset.ldquoShe is only , shersquos just lost her dad and wants to put something on his grave to honour him.The pair hope the person responsible ldquofeels ashamed and s the bouquet.

title: scott-glynn-remembered-walk-scott-may
story: The walk was set up by Tranent after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Scott passed away on New Yearrsquos Day.Since its inception in , the event has raised more than pound, for local charities and good causes.Last Friday, on social media, the Walk With Scott Foundation announced: ldquoWalk with Scott  is on!ldquoStick Saturday, May , , in your diaries, get those walking shoes out, and look out for further information in the coming weeks.Last year, more than  people turned out to complete a .-mile walk around East Lothian in aid of the foundation.The group set out from Cockenzie, heading to Musselburgh they followed the River Esk to Whitecraig, then went along the old Pencaitland railway, on to Boggs Holdings, up through Butterdean Woods, then along to Longniddry before turning back along the coast road to Cockenzie.For more information, search lsquoWalk With Scott Foundationrsquo on Facebook.

title: east-lothians-burns-clubs-holding-burns-suppers-weekend
story: Suppers and other events celebrating the le and work of Scotlandrsquos national poet Robert Burns take place in towns and villages across East Lothian this week.The first events take place today , with Tranent  Burns Club hosting a supper at the townrsquos East Lothian Co-operative Bowling Club.Those who wish to go along can attend from .pm for a pm start.Knox Academy are not holding a supper this year but North Berwick High School are and join in with their own celebration at the school, organised by their PTA, from .pm.Meanwhile, Haddington Burns Club celebrates with a Burns supper in the townrsquos bowling club at pm.The supper is chaired by Haddingtonian Gordon Bathgate and the Immortal Memory given by Dr Peter Hughes, past president of the World Burns Federation.Other speakers include Steven Illingworth from Knox Academy, Keith Wallace and George Macintosh, who will give the Toast to the Lassies.Tickets are available at Mains on Haddington High Street and from Alan Sheerin on  .More entertainment is provided by Tantallon Golf Club in North Berwick, with attendees gathering at pm for a .pm start.The day after , North Berwick Burns Club convene at the townrsquos Macdonald Marine Hotel, .pm for pm anyone interested in getting tickets should message North Berwick Burns Club on Facebook.East Lothian Yacht Club have cancelled their Burns supper this year but Craigleith Burns Clubrsquos is still going ahead, held in the Nether Abbey Hotel in North Berwick, .pm for pm ndash entertainment is to be provided by Davie Holt.Prestonpans Airts Burns Club holds its Burns supper in the townrsquos Gothenburg, .pm for pm.The Station Yard Micropub on Dunbarrsquos Station Road hosts a iety of performances of live Scottish music from todayuntil Sunday.A selection of Scottish gins, beers and whiskies will be on offer, alongside a twist on the traditional haggis, neeps and tatties.Seton Burns Club hold their own celebrations next month.The group hosts its menrsquos supper next Saturdayin Cockenzie Royal British Legion, .pm for pm, tickets pound.The clubrsquos lads and lassies supper follows on February , with tickets pound, also in the Legion, .pm for pm.Message Seton Burns Club on Facebook for tickets.

title: wetherspoon-pubs-tell-parents-children-can-two-drinks
story: Its a question thats sparked a debate on social media after it was revealed Wetherspoon pubs limit parents to two alcoholic drinks eachthey have children with them.The rule came to light after a picture was taken of a poster in a pub in Kent.The poster, which has since been taken down, read: "As part of our licensing it is our responsibility to ensure that we are protecting children from harm."Therefore adults in charge of children will be allowed to have one alcoholic drink and a further alcoholic drink with a sit-down meal."It has been a crime since  to be drunk in charge of a child under the age of seven in a public place.The offence can be punished by a fine or up to a month in jail.A spokesman for Wetherspoon,which has a pub on Musselburghs Bridge Street, The David Macbeth Moir,said: "The manager took the decision to put the poster in the pub to emphasise to customers that she would not allow parents to drink while their children were running round uncontrolled in the pub."The notice had a positive effect, with mostly good feedback."Wetherspoonadded: "There is a guideline, though not a policy, that we will serve the adult a maximum of two alcoholic drinks with their meal."The reason is that we dont want children being unruly in the pubs and parents thinking they can continue to drink while this happens."

title: lion-king-magical-stage-production-spine-tingling-sensation
story: The loveable and heartwarming story of Simbas rollercoaster journey to become King of the Pride Lands is a firm family cartoon favourite but can it really be transformed into a theatrical extravaganza It certainly can!From the moment the lights dimmed in the Edinburgh Playhouse you are transported into a magical kingdom immersed with the most amazing colour and sounds as the anthemic Circle of Le  song filled the room.Other stand out songs included the fun, lighthearted, I Just Cant Wait to be King performed by young Simba and Nala and the poignant, He lives in You, thanks to the genius of Elton John and Tim Rice.Each character was performed like a masterpiece by an impressive and erse cast but special mention has to go to Thandazile Soni whose portrayal of Rafiki had the audience spellbound with her humour, top vocals and creative take on the famous mandrill.Richard Hurst as Scar brought the classic baddie to le and Jean-Luc Guizonne was majestic in his rendition of Mufasa.While it was a laugh a minute from the brilliant Matthew Forbes as Zazu who couldnt help but make a gag about the rivalry between the Capital and Glasgow.From the infectious laughs of the dimwitted hyenas to the heartwarming friendship of duo Timon and Pumbaa, you connected with every character - a credit to the charm of the story.The attention to detail was phenomenal from the unique movement of characters shadowing animals to a tee to the human props that brought the set to le.The scenery, costumes, puppetry in their entirety were breathtaking, taking you into African savannah paradise.The Lion King is full of good fun, show stomping tunes and a treat for your eyes and ears which showcases the best of the West End right on our doorstep in Edinburgh.With  years competing as one of the all-time most successful productions, youll be left wondering why you didnt go and see this sooner.This show is the King of the stage.

title: car-plummets-20ft-off-dunbar-sea-wall-onto-beach
story: Thankfully,no-one was in the Vauxhall Zafira when it suffered suspected handbrake failure and plummeted onto Dunbars East Beach from the towns Lamer Street at about .am.There were walkers on the beach but they were not nearby.The Courier understands the cars owners were on a day trip to Dunbar from Edinburgh.One passer-by said: "Luckily, no-one was in the car at the time - it was not the day out that the car owners had planned!"A tow truck appeared later in the day to take the battered car - which had flipped onto its roof - off the beach.

title: east-coast-buses-fares-rise-weekend
story: Adult singles fares will rise by p across all zones. Child singles will also be increasing by p across all zones, but up to three children under five can travel free with any fare-paying customer.YoungScot tickets will increase by p across zones one, five and six and p across zones two, three and four.Adult DAYtickets for County and CountyPLUS tickets will increase by p, with child DAY-ticket equivalents increasing by p. There will also be a p increase in County Family DAYtickets however, no increase will be applied on CountyPLUS family DAYtickets.Adult Network DAYtickets will increase by pound and a p increase will be applied to Child Network DAYtickets.Nigel Serafini, commercial director at Lothian Buses, which operates East Coast Buses, said: ldquoEast Coast Buses is committed to providing environmentally sustainable, best value travel.ldquoAs our operating costs continue to rise and we continue to invest in fleet, people, training and our customer offering, we will be making changes to fares.ldquoAs well as continuing our investment in new environmentally-friendly vehicles across , we are currently in the process of renewing our real time customer information system. This system plays a vital role in helping us monitor and control services, as well as allowing customers to track bus arrivals.ldquoOur revised fares continue to represent excellent value for money and remain amongst the lowest in the UK.

title: fringe-sea-2020-basement-jaxx-candi-staton-announced
story: This yearrsquos festival opens on August  and runs until August .Headlining the opening night are Basement Jaxx, the chart-topping electronic dance duo made up of Felix Buxton and Simon Ratclfe.American singer songwriter Candi Staton, whose hits include Young Hearts Run Free, and Stornoway folk rockers Peat and Diesel will perform on August . Also confirmed are Huey Morgan, frontman of the Fun Lovinrsquo Criminalship-hop musicians Dat Brass and The Blues Band, who take to the stage on August .Most of the entertainment will be held in the harbour area, with plenty of other events taking place throughout the town.North Berwick Fry will be hosting a number of music events, providing entertainment to those enjoying a fish supper.There will be about  events at Fringe by the Sea this year. As well as musical performances there will be comedy, author talks, a kidsrsquo zone, arts and crafts, music workshops, open mic sessions, wellbeing and yoga, guided walks, wild swimming, art exhibitions, street performers and plenty of local food stalls.Fringe by the Sea will be working closely with its community partners, including the Scottish Seabird Centre and NB Movies.Jackie Shuttleworth, programme manager, said: ldquoWersquore really pleased to have secured these artists to kickstart the festival programme.ldquoOver the next few months, we will be adding dozens more acts to the line-up for Fringe by the Sea, which is now a firm fixture in the Scottish festival scene.ldquoAs a not-for-profit organisation, we rely on the generous support of our funders and sponsors to help make the festival happen. We say a big thank you to those whorsquove committed their support and we are thrilled to welcome on board Mactaggart  Mickel as master sponsor.ldquoTheir support will help us deliver an extra special festival experience for our , visitors.Tickets, available by clicking here,go on sale today .

title: national-museum-flight-plans-fell-299-trees-move-planes
story: Plans for the new visitor base and exhibition centre reveal a -metre-wide swathe will need to be cut through a tree belt separating the building from the museumrsquos current base at East Fortune, with a total of  trees to be felledthe plans are approved.The move has angered local residents, who say that other sites could have been considered which would not require the destruction of the woodlands.And the Woodland Trust has lodged an objection, highlightingthat the area facing destruction is next to an ancient woodland site known as Big Wood which will be affected.It said there would be ldquodirect loss of irreplaceable ancient woodland under the plans.The museumrsquos architects say other sites on the current museum site are protected,as the airfieldis a Scheduled Monument.In their report on plans for the new centre, which would include car parking for nearly  vehicles, they say that three of the historic planes on display at the current museum site need to be brought indoors to protect them and will go on display in the new centre, alongside Concorde, which is currently in a hangar at the museum.They say: ldquoThe Comet has been identied to have the greatest wingspanand requires at least a m-wide swathe to be cut in the tree belt.ldquoDue to the conservation requirement to preserve the integrity of the aircraft as objects in the national collection, the wings cannot be detached and, therefore, in order to facilitate the project, the tree beltto the north of the proposed site requiresto be removed.The Comet and Vickers Viscount are described as being of ldquonational and international signicance and are currently on display outdoors alongside a BAC- and will be moved into the new centre.Concorde will also be moved and a Vulcan Bomber currently on display outdoors will move into its current hangar.A tree report said that  trees would need to be removed to accommodate the project, with some dating back nearly more than  years, covering . hectares of woodland on the Gilmerton Estate, next toBig Wood.It estimates an initial carbon loss of  tonnes of CO equivalentsfrom the removal of the trees but says it would be ldquopaid back by planting nearly  new trees.Planning officers are recommending approval ofplanswhich received  objections, many centring onthe impact on the woodlands and wildle, with claims there might be bat roosts in the trees, as well as badgers living there.The Woodland Trust told the council: ldquoThe trust objects to the planning application on the basis of disturbance and loss to Big Wood.ldquoWhen land use is changed to a more intensive use such as in this situation, plant and animal populations are exposed to environmental impact from outside of the woodland.ldquoThese detrimental edge effects can result in changes to the environmental conditions within the woodland and consequently affect the woodrsquos stable condition.ldquoDetrimental edge effects have been shown to penetrate woodland, causing changes in ancient woodland characteristicsthat extend up to three times the canopy height in from the forest edges.The Woodland Trust also says a -metre buffer zone is needed between Big Wood and the proposed parking area and fencing in place to stop any encroachment during construction the plans are approved.It warns: ldquoAncient woodland is irreplaceable, once gone it cannot be recreated.Councillors will rule on the proposal at a meeting of East Lothian Councils planning committee on Tuesday.

title: hoarders-sitting-216-gadget-goldmine
story: Weve all got a dusty old phone or two sat in a drawer, abandoned when the latest upgrade came along.Each person has at least one old mobile gathering dust in drawers that could be worth on average poundsold second hand, a new study by gadget and gaming shop CeX shows.And each British household has one further old games console and four unused games which are worth a total of around pound, according to a survey by CeX, Britainrsquos leading buy and sell technology chain.However, only three in are selling their gadgets to secondhand stores or online hellip a quarter of people simply canrsquot be bothered to sell their gadgets, nearly two in fiveare counting down the day until payday in January.Across our old mobiles, tablets, consoles, cameras and games, we have a whopping pound gathering dust ndash enough forflights to Palma for two and two nights at a hotel with beachfront cocktail cash to spare!Hugh Man, co-founder and chairman at CeX said: ldquoAll the old phones, tech, consoles and discs we forget about, still have a lot of value. Most people have no idea they have literally little piles of treasure that have been sitting for years in their cupboards.The average old iPhone s can fetch up to pound second hand and even the Nokia  ndash which sold over  million worldwide ndash is worth a tenner. An old PlayStation PS can be worth pound and Xbox One pound. Add in a few games and the likes of Minecraft , Call of Duty Modern Warfareand Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wildwill fetch you a small fortune.TOP  MOST LUCRATIVE MOBILE TRADE-INS:Elsewhere around our homes, nearly a quarter of people have an unused laptop, a third cast away headphones and a further  in  have littered desks, drawers and cupboards with computer accessories such as hard drives and graphics cards.A third say the money they would get from selling their gadgets is not worth the hassle, however almost half of those who did go to use a secondhand store to sell their gadgets said the selling process was really easy.More than a quartersaid they were pleasantly surprised with the money they got back.

title: musselburgh-racecourse-staff-receive-1-000-bonus
story: The course is expected to turn the   deficit of pound, into a pound, closing balance at the end of the   financial year, with its team of staff credited with being the driving force behind the turnaround.And at a meeting this month of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee , members, who oversee the governance of the course, agreed to give each of the -strong team a pound, bonus to reflect their efforts.Committee member Robert Miller-Bakewell proposed the bonus for all staff during the meeting, which was supported by committee convenor Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell and fellow member Roy Anderson Green.Remaining committee members in attendance, Musselburgh councillors Katie Mackie and Andrew Forrest, voted against the bonus but did not give reasons for their position.Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth had told the committee that, after what had been a very bad previous year for the course, in which it had seen the Beast from the East, equine flu, and a dry summer affect fixtures and runners, this financial year had proved extremely good.He said: ldquoFor all the badluck we had last year [ ], we have been paid back with good luck this year [ ].ldquoFull credit has to go to the staff, everyone has kept focus and kept doing their jobs.Boosting the turnaround in finances this year is the predicted income from the sale of assets to the new operators of Musselburgh Racecourse which is expected to bring in around pound, on top of profits of pound, from the year.At the MRAC meeting members, were told that new operators Chester Racecourse were now expected to take over on March .Legal adviser Carlo Grilli said the British Horseracing Authority had issued a licence to Musselburgh Racecourse to cover it up to the takeover and talks were ongoing with staff.

title: bid-create-path-spott-dunbar
story: Spott Community Association wants a safe and direct route between the village and the nearby town created for cyclists and walkers.It has been awarded pound, through Sustrans Scotlandrsquos Places for Everyone programme, which is funded by Transport Scotland, to carry out a feasibility study for a traffic-free route.Anne Lyall, chairwoman of the group, said: ldquoWersquore really pleased to have secured this signicant funding and are excited to see what solutions are proposed.The town and village are . miles apart.A project launch event will be held at Spott Village Hall on Tuesday at .pm.A presentation will be given and there will be an opportunity for questions to be asked.Spott Community Association is looking forward to seeing what is proposed and will consult the community and report back with some options.Once a preferred option has been decided, an application will be made for further funding to carry out more detailed work.

title: road-linking-tranent-prestonpans-railway-station-close
story: East Lothian Council is applying to close Johnnie Copersquos Road, a popular route to Prestonpans train station and used as a shortcut between Prestonpans and the Tranent areas.The road was due to close in the mid-s after the Tranent bypass section of the A was completed.However, a report last week to East Lothian Councilrsquos cabinet said that the former Lothian Regional Council, the responsible local authority at the time, never introduced the proper regulations.Councillors have now approved a plan to apply for traffic orders to shut the road, with vehicle access blocked from the Tranent end and only available from Prestonpans for a short distance to allow traffic to reach Prestonpansrail stationrsquos overspill car park and nearby houses.A council spokesman said: ldquoAt the time of construction of the A bypass, a farm accommodation bridge [over the bypass] was put in place. At the time, the former Lothian Regional Council intended to close the road to traffic and redetermine the road for pedestrians and cyclists only. The relevant order was not promoted and put in place at the time, and it is now proposed that this is implemented in the interests of safety.The council also agreed to apply for traffic orders for a range of restrictions, including introducing yellow lines in the long-stay car park near Tesco Haddington, making a trial mph speed limit in Dunbar permanent, and introducing mph speed limits around mph roads approaching the new town of Blindwells. The orders will now go out for public consultation and are likely to take  months to implementapproved.The road is named after Sir John Cope, whose government forces were defeated at the  Battle of Prestonpans by Bonnie Prince Charliersquos Jacobites, before Cope fled to Berwick-upon-Tweed. A famous folk song, Hey, Johnnie Cope, Are Ye Walking Yet  commemorates the battle.

title: former-home-counselling-service-turned-apartments
story: Harrison HuntLtd will convert the St Andrews Centre,  Bayswell Road, into four apartments.The building was previously the home of CrossReach, which offers care to people of all ages.However, the Church of Scotland service moved to Prestonpans in March last year.Plans to transform the building were approved by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department. Planning officials took into account that the building lies within the townrsquos conservation area.A report outlining the reasons for approving the scheme noted: ldquoThe proposed alterations are relatively minor in scale and nature.The proposals were backed by the townrsquos community council. A letter to the local authority noted the change of use was supported to prevent the building becoming decayed, provided the development was sympathetic to the buildingrsquos architectural details.In the design and access statement, Harrison HuntLtd said: ldquoThe old manse is currently empty following the decision by the former tenant, Church of Scotland, to relocate their social work services to an alternative location.ldquoGiven the previous and historic residential use of the building, it is now considered timely and appropriate to revert this vacant building back to a residential use.

title: scottish-minister-toasts-pear-tree-nurserys-success
story: Maree Todd MSP visited Pear Tree Nursery on Meadowpark last Thursday with Purnima Tanuku, chief executive of National Day Nurseries Association , to toast Milliersquos Mark.The award, developed in conjunction with NDNA, aims to keep children as safe as possible in nursery, through promoting staff training, policies and procedures well above national standards.Milliersquos Trust was set up by Stockport couple Dan and Joanne Thompson following the death of their daughter Millie, who choked on food in a nursery. They believed that everyone should have access to first aid training, with the award so far having been presented to  nurseries south of the Border.Ms Todd said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is committed to continual training opportunities for early learning and childcare workers, and Milliersquos Mark provides a great opportunity to upskill staff to be able to do their best for children in their care in an emergency.ldquoNurseries that have signed up to Milliersquos Mark will be able to tell parents that they are trained to a high standard in first aid for babies and toddlers, and Irsquom very pleased that staff have already undertaken these additional training opportunities where they are available.Ms Tanuku also offered her congratulations to the nursery, whose branch on West Road has now achieved the same award.She said: ldquoWe are thrilled that Milliersquos Mark has been well received across Scotland and are very proud of the staff of Pear Tree nurseries for their hard work and dedication.ldquoAs well as becoming the first nursery to receive Milliersquos Mark in Scotland, the group now has three nurseries which have been accredited. More nurseries are working towards the award, which we hope will become the standard for all childcare providers.Gillian Harvey, manager of Pear Tree Nursery, was delighted to achieve the award.She said: ldquoOur children are out in the community and on our forest site often, so we reviewed first aid not only within the building but in dferent locations.ldquoThrough Milliersquos Mark audit we were able to gauge staff confidence in dferent first aid areas and work together to improve everybodyrsquos confidence.ldquoOur whole team are involved, including lunch cover, supply staff, office staff, chef and all our practitioners. This gives all children, staff and parents extra reassurance that their children are safe and well cared for.

title: public-meeting-discuss-car-park-proposals
story: East Lothian Council is keen to create a new car park between Woodbush and Church Street.The exhibition will focus on the proposed -space car park but will also look at wider issues in the town, including the introduction of a time limit at Abbeylands car park and the possibility of an increase in parking spaces at the townrsquos railway station.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of Dunbar Community Council, agreed that discussions needed to take place surrounding parking in the town.She said: ldquoMy understanding from speaking or listening to people, the general sense isparking for the station was sorted out then pressure on the car parks such as Abbeylands would be massively improved.ldquoThere is plainly an issue with people abusing the time limit [for parking] on High Street, as stated in the councilrsquos transport strategy.ldquoIf there was better management of parking on High Street, the problem would be ameliorated.ldquoThe perception is the station is the one that is really driving the problem, particularly at the south end of the town.ldquoThat would seem to be a priority to try to get that sorted.Mrs Swan highlighted the increasing need for people to use public transport, as well as to travel on bicycle or on foot, and called for a full analysis to be carried out.She added: ldquoBefore we put tarmac or concrete over grass, we need to have the story worked out.The exhibition, which takes place between .pm and pm in the Town House, will feature a display showing initial designs of the proposal for the new car park.A planning application is already with the local authorityrsquos planning department.That shows that the proposed new car park would be accessed by Lamer Street and Woodbush, with a metal staircase connecting the site ndash which is currently a patch of grass ndash to nearby Church Street.Mrs Swan told the Courier that neighbours of the proposed development were ldquostill strongly opposed to the plans.Officers from East Lothian Council will be on hand at the exhibition ndash which was originally planned for earlier this month but then cancelled ndash to discuss any issues.Abbeylands car park, off High Street, currently has more than  spaces with no time restrictions.However, concerns have been raised at community meetings that it is full from early in the morning, with people parking there and using the railway station to continue their journey.Similarly, discussions are taking place between the local authority and Network Rail with a view to increasing the size of the car park at the nearby railway station.

title: driver-caught-116mph-city-edinburgh-bypass
story: Ben Cockburn, of New Houses, Athelstaneford, was clocked speeding at mph when he was driving between the Sherfhall and Old Craighall roundabouts.Cockburn was originally charged with a dangerous driving offence by speeding, accelerating aggressively and crossing solid white lines during the incident in October .But the -year-old agreed to plead guilty to a reduced charge of speeding when he appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court on Monday.Solicitor Angela Craig said that her client had ldquono immediate excuse for driving so fast other than that he was ldquoin a rush at the time.Ms Craig asked Sherf Adrian Cottam not to ban Cockburn from the road as his use of a vehicle was ldquoessentially part of his business and was an ldquointegral part of his job.Sherf Cottam said that there had been ldquoa signicant dference in the charge he had been facing and what he had pleaded guilty to and agreed not to issue a road ban.Instead, the sherf placed five points on Cockburnrsquos driving licence and ordered him to pay a fine of pound. He will pay the fine at pound per month.Cockburn pleaded guilty to driving at mph at the A City Bypass on October , .

title: bid-bring-back-outdoor-swimming-pool
story: Gill Surfleet is among a group of ldquolike-minded residents who have formed BBOP .She grew up in the town and used the old outdoor pool next to the harbour ndash now home to a dinghy park ndash regularly.The -year-old mum-of-two moved away in her late teens to attend university, ing two years ago.Gill, who was involved in the campaign against the poolrsquos closure in the s, said: ldquoThe pool was a great community resource and social gathering space used by a lot of people I was part of the last group of people to use it.ldquoThe initial campaign wasnrsquot successful but I want to try again ndash I feel like itrsquos now or never.ldquoPeople that used the pool as a child have had their own kids and want them using it. There are over , kids in the high school and there is not a lot going on for them.The online petition was launched last Thursday and has already received more than , signatures.She said: ldquoWhen I was on maternity leave I started talking to people about the pool when out on High Street, askingit would be feasible, and there is support to have it brought back.ldquoI didnrsquot expect that many people to sign it this early: there is an appetite for it to be done and I am starting the conversation.The group is seeking more members and volunteers to help their cause, including architects and lawyers.Gill realised that the pool might not be able toto the harbour but had not yet fully examined possible alternative locations.And because they had only just launched, funding ideas were still at a very early stage though they are keen to work with community organisations and East Lothian Council to realise their dream.Judy Lockhart, chair of North Berwick Community Council, said: ldquoThe community council was interested to hear about the petition.ldquoThe pool certainly brings back a lot of good memories and, like many others, I learned to swim in it!ldquoIt will be interesting to see how the petition develops and, as with all local groups, the organisers are welcome to get in touch with usthey wish.Jeremy Findlay, ward councillor, said: ldquoI have no problem with the concept of bringing this back but it must be on the basis that this is the will of the majority of the town and also that it does not have a detrimental impact on existing organisations that use this area.The petition is at you.degrees.org.uk petitions bring-back-north-berwick-outdoor-pool-bbop

title: dunbar-lifeboat-shop-volunteers-top-shops
story: Dunbar RNLIrsquos shop on the townrsquos High Street has been named the best performing RNLI shop in Scotland.Opened on High Street in , it sells a wide iety of goods, from homeware and toys to greeting cards and Galileo thermometers.Money is then poured back into the le-saving charity.Shop manager Ken Headley said: ldquoWe have been there before but this year we knew Portpatrick [RNLI shop] had a really good year.ldquoIt is really good to know we are still at the top.ldquoWe open almost every day of the year and basically we have got a good range of stock.ldquoWe have got  really good volunteers so we are never stuck for getting it open.Mr Headley, who previously worked as a banker in London, initially became manager for what he thought would be ldquoa short while.However, he remains at the helm alongside we Marie.Paying tribute to those who volunteer for the RNLI offshore, he said: ldquoI have got great respect for the guys who actually go out in the boats.ldquoIf they are prepared to go every day, I donrsquot see why we cannot be prepared to open the shop.Mark Lees, chairman of Dunbar Leboat Station, was ldquoexceptionally proud of what the shop volunteers had achieved in the past year.He said: ldquoTo be the most successful leboat fundraising retail outlet in Scotland is a huge testament to all the hard work of the whole team, all of whom are volunteers and give up their time selflessly.ldquoNaturally, there is a huge partnership with the community in this success, because it is the support of the community that not only buys the great products we have but also, effectively, saves lives.ldquoI have a personal belief that the community are so supportive of lsquotheirrsquo leboat station because they not only see the lesaving activities the crew and station participate in but also all the other community work the crew and station support in Dunbar and beyond.ldquoWhen we put that alongside the work our fantastic fundraising volunteers do, we understand just how fortunate we are to be supported by such an outstanding community. We can never be complacent, though, because despite having the most successful retail shop in Scotland, and a fundraising team the envy of every other leboat station in the country, we still rely on the support of the wider RNLI to make up the shortfall in funds to run our station.ldquoThatrsquos why we are so grateful to the team and all of Dunbar for their unstinting support.

title: new-emojis-approved-2020
story: In total,  new characters and images have been approved for addition to the emoji library, regulator the Unicode Consortium announced.The  list also includes a person in a veil, as well as emoji for bubble tea, and a person bottle-feeding a baby.# Now approved:  new emojis for  #Emoji https:t.co SojQuXZvv pic sHpGDsSalLast year, a number of same-sex couple and gender-neutral emoji were added to the library to improve representation, but there was criticism over the non-inclusion of the transgender flag ndash which has now been added alongside the transgender symbol.The Unicode Consortiumrsquos list is the central bank of approved emoji, with companies including Apple, Google and Microsoft then applying stylised versions of the designs to their own operating systems.The website Emojipedia, which is part of the Unicode Consortium and details icons found in updates, said: ldquoAnnounced today by the Unicode Consortium, the  new emojis form part of Emoji . and will come to most s in the second half of .New in Emoji .: Transgender Flag #Emoji https:t.co DTnXZxHM pic yoEUHZUTDldquoVariations of existing emojis now approved for  include a woman or gender-inclusive person in a tuxedo, as well as a gender-neutral person or a man in a veil. These, along with other approved emojis, will be coming to phones later this year.ldquoAlso included in this update is a gender-inclusive alternative to Santa Claus and Mrs Claus, named Mx Claus. This addition is part of an ongoing effort to make more consistent set of gender options across the board, and expands upon the  new gender-neutral emojis added in late  as part of Emoji ..Emojipedia noted that some versions of the new emoji, including the transgender flag and the woman in a tuxedo, are already available on Twitter.Jeff Ingold, head of media engagement at LGBT campaigns group Stonewall, said: ldquoTaking action to make tools of communication, like emojis, more inclusive and erse is always a welcome step.ldquoSo wersquore glad to see the inclusion of more gender-neutral emojis and a trans flag emoji. Visibility is really important and companies can always be thinking of more ways to promote trans equality.Also among the list of approved emoji is a ninja, a pinched finger gesture, a seal, a bison and a dodo.No release dates have been confirmed for the emoji on dferent operating systems, although they are traditionally rolled out later in the year when new versions of Applersquos iOS and Googlersquos Android software are released to the public.

story: Adam Cook, who is deputy store manager at Tranentrsquos Asda store, was joined on an impressive journey by neighbours George Jack and Anderson Lima in aid of Cancer Research UK.The trio title: petition-massive-tree-cull-gains-1-500-signatures
story: The planned removal of the tree belt, which includes over  matures trees and  early mature ones, is to allow them to move four planes at the Museum of Flight, East Fortune, to a new visitor centre they want to build on adjoining land.However, the destruction of the trees has sparked a furious reaction with an online petition attracting more than ,signatures in hours.The Woodland Trust has lodged an objection to the plans, which will be put to East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee on Tuesday.It said that it believed the planned centre on the Gilmerton Estate and destruction of the tree belt which lies next to ancient woodland known as Big Wood would lead to a ldquodirect loss of irreplaceable ancient woodland.However,National Museums Scotland have said their plans will not affect ancient woodland and they will replant  trees.And they refute claims that they had not considered other neighbouring sites before opting to place the new centre on the other side of the trees.A National Museums Scotland spokeswoman said:ldquoThe National Museum of Flight is the best preserved second world war airfield in the UK.ldquoIt is a Scheduled Monument and as a consequence it would not be possible to construct a new building on the current site. There are also signicant restrictions on developments around the site.ldquoWe considered all possible options for the location of our new building, including the fields to the west of the site.ldquoWe liaised closely with Historic Environment Scotland to identy a site which would minimise any impact on the Scheduled Monument.ldquoThe current proposal has been specically chosen for this reason. The natural topography has been used as part of the design. Building into the slope of the ground in the proposed location allows the buildingrsquos height to be signicantly reduced. Historic Environment Scotland have already given Scheduled Monument Consent for the development.Campaigners against the proposal insist NMS has not explored all options and point to a Freedom of Information response issued by them in September which confirmed they ldquohad no written or other communication with anyone other than the Gilmerton Estate, including with respect to the potential acquisition of property.The petition, lodged on Change.org and called lsquoStop National Museums of Scotland Killing  Trees!rsquo, calls on museum bosses to abandon their plans and look for an alternative site.It says: ldquoThe Woodland Trust, Rewilding East Lothian and many locals strongly oppose this.ldquoAt a time of climate emergency and with wildle habitats already in rapid decline, it is extremely shortsighted to chop down a mature swathe of wood. Planting young trees as a ldquoreplacement is not sufficient.Local campaigners have also written to East Lothian councillors who sit on the planning committee urging them to reject the plans.They argue that the museum has made no efforts to seek an alternative site before opting for the land on the other side of the trees and should have done so before presenting the proposals.They said: ldquoNo process of seeking alternative sites has been presented as part of the required mitigation hierarchy and point to fields to the west of the museum site as an option which has not been explored.The petition can be viewed here.
